thread.title_full: Death toll in Utah flash floods goes up to sevenTravelandtourworld.com

author: travelandtourworld.com
title: Death toll in Utah flash floods goes up to sevenTravelandtourworld.com
text:
Death toll in Utah flash floods goes up to seven Published on : Friday, September 18, 2015
The death toll in a flash flood has gone up as search crews in Zion National Park in Utah have found the body of the seventh person killed earlier this week, National Park Service spokesman David Eaker said Thursday.
The flood struck Monday afternoon while a group of seven people were in Keyhole Canyon, a narrow canyon formed by water wearing through rock over the centuries, the park service said.
Eaker said search teams found the seventh body Thursday morning in Pine Creek Canyon, one of the park’s difficult-to-reach areas. They had not searched the area, located downstream from Keyhole Canyon, earlier because of the threat of more flash floods, he said.
The people in the group were between 40 and 50 years old and from California and Nevada, park spokeswoman Alyssa Baltrus said.
The park service has not identified any of the victims but the sheriff’s department in Ventura County, California, said in a statement that one of the people killed was Steve Arthur, a sergeant and 21-year veteran with the department.
His wife, Linda Arthur, was the last person missing, the sheriff’s department said.
The park service regularly warns people about the possibility of flash floods, according to the Facebook page of the park.
